title.narrative: Improving the Business Environment for Social Enterprises to foster social inclusion of disadvantaged groups in Cameroon

description.narrative:
In Cameroon, strongeconomic growth has not translated into poverty reduction, as population growth outpaces poverty reduction and the number of poor increased by 12 per cent to 8.1 million people between 2007 and 2014. Poverty is also marked by high spatial and social inequities. Poverty rates have only marginally decreased between 2001 and 2014, from 40.2 to 37.5 per cent, with striking and increasing regional disparities: the rural regions of the Far North and the North have poverty levels of 7 per cent and are home to 55.8 per cent of the poor, whereas in urban areas poverty is at 4.8 per cent (3.2 per cent of the poor).
The aim of poverty reduction efforts must be to reduce these spatial and social inequalities of which poverty is an outcome. Improving the terms of participation in society, particularly for people who are disadvantaged, requires enhancing opportunities, access to resources, voice and respect for rights. To drive social inclusion, it is necessary both to address the causes of exclusion and to actively work towards inclusion.
The social and solidarity economy (SSE) has emerged as local collective action to address raising inequalities and social inclusion of certain population groups emerging from market and governance failures to deal with these issues.
Contextually in Cameroon, the Social Economy refers to companies and organizations - in particular cooperatives, mutuals, associations, foundations and social enterprises - which are specifically producing goods, services and knowledge while pursuing both economic and social objectives and are promoting solidarity (a practical definition agreed at the Tripartite Conference in Johannesburg in October 2009).
Despite their potential and economic importance, organizations of the social economy in Cameroon face many constraints that are of organizational, institutional, financial, legal and technological nature.
At the level of the national strategic planning framework, the choices of the five (5) strategic axes operated by the government for the operationalization of the strategy for the development of the social economy are the following: (i) the improvement of the knowledge of the social economy sector; (ii) the adoption of an appropriate institutional, legislative and regulatory framework; (iii) the promotion of collective or group entrepreneurship; (iv) facilitating access of ESOs to finance, and; (v) promoting a social economy culture.
The UNIDO project will assist the Government of Cameroon in achieving its strategy for the development of the social economy, with a particular focus on axis (ii) the adoption of an appropriate institutional, legislative and regulatory framework.
